title: 112_hr4383
content:
The Act titled "Streamlining Permitting of American Energy Act of 2012" includes provisions for permit application timelines, solar and wind right-of-way rental reform, administrative protest documentation reform, Federal energy permit coordination improvement, administration of current law, policies for American projects, and judicial review. TITLE IV--JUDICIAL REVIEW

This section includes definitions, exclusive venue for civil actions related to energy projects, timely filing requirements, expedited hearing processes, standards of review, limitations on injunctions and attorneys' fees, and legal standing. Section 17(p)(2) of the Mineral Leasing Act is amended to require the Secretary to decide on issuing a permit to drill within 30 days of receiving an application, with the option to extend the deadline for up to two periods of 15 days each with written notice to the applicant. The notice must include specific reasons for the delay and an expected final decision date. The Secretary must provide clear reasons for denial of an application, along with an opportunity to address any deficiencies. If a decision is not made within 60 days of receiving the application, it is deemed approved. The Secretary must provide clear reasons for denial of a permit application and allow for resubmission within a 10-day period. The Secretary must issue or deny a resubmitted application within 10 days. A $6,500 permit processing fee is required per application, collected at the final decision. 50% of the fees collected are transferred to. 50 percent of fees collected are transferred to the field office for processing protests, leases, and permits under this Act. SEC. 102 of the bill addresses the reform of solar and wind right-of-way rental fees, stipulating that 50 percent of fees collected annually will be retained by the Secretary of the Interior for processing permits and applications related to renewable energy development on Bureau of Land Management lands. SEC. 201 amends the Mineral Leasing Act to include a $5,000 documentation fee for protests on leases, rights of way, or drilling permits, with 50% of fees staying in the field office for processing. The Secretary of the Interior will establish a Federal Permit Streamlining Project in every Bureau of Land Management field office for permitting energy projects on Federal land. Within 90 days of enactment, a memorandum of understanding will be entered into with the Secretary of Agriculture, the Administrator of the EPA, and the Chief of the Army Corps of Engineers for state participation. The Governor of any State with energy projects on Federal lands must sign a memorandum of understanding. Within 30 days of signing, Federal parties will assign qualified staff to Bureau of Land Management field offices with expertise in regulatory issues related to the office, including consultations under the Endangered Species Act and permits under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. The Governor of any State with energy projects on Federal lands must sign a memorandum of understanding. Federal parties will assign qualified staff to Bureau of Land Management field offices with expertise in regulatory issues related to the office, including pollution control, Clean Air Act, National Forest Management Act, and National Environmental Policy Act. Each assigned employee must report to the Field Managers, handle energy project issues, and comply with home agency authorities. The Secretary will assign additional personnel to Bureau of Land Management field offices to ensure effective approval and implementation of energy projects on Federal lands. Funding for these personnel will come from Department of the Interior reforms. The term "energy projects" in this section includes oil, natural gas, coal, and other energy projects as defined by the Secretary. Nothing in this section affects the operation of any Federal or State law or any delegation of authority made by the head of a Federal agency whose employees are participating in the Project. SEC. 302. The Secretary of the Interior will not need to find extraordinary circumstances when administering section 390 of the Energy Policy Act of 2005. SEC. 303. Policies regarding buying, building, and working for America. Congress intends for this Act to support the growth of the domestic energy sector, benefiting American manufacturing, transportation, and service industries by utilizing U.S. workers. The deployment of personnel and materials under this Act should promote American technology and manufacturing, creating good jobs and industrial facilities to enhance access to U.S. energy resources. The Secretary of the Interior is required to prioritize the use of American workers whenever possible. To support domestic energy sector growth, the Act prioritizes the use of U.S. workers and equipment in mineral resource development. TITLE IV--JUDICIAL REVIEW

SEC. 401. DEFINITIONS.

In this Act, a "covered civil action" refers to a civil action with a claim under section 702 of title 5, United States Code, related to agency action affecting a "covered energy project" on Federal lands. The term "covered energy project" includes leasing Federal lands for energy exploration, development, and production, excluding disputes over lease obligations. SEC. 402. EXCLUSIVE VENUE FOR CERTAIN CIVIL ACTIONS RELATING TO COVERED ENERGY PROJECTS.

Venue for covered civil actions lies in the district court where the project or leases are located or proposed.

SEC. 403. TIMELY FILING.

Covered civil actions must be filed within 90 days of the final Federal agency action.

SEC. 404. EXPEDITION IN HEARING AND DETERMINING THE ACTION.

Courts must expedite the hearing and determination of covered civil actions.

SEC. 405. STANDARD OF REVIEW.

Administrative findings are presumed correct in judicial review, rebuttable only by preponderance of evidence. SEC. 406. LIMITATION ON INJUNCTION AND PROSPECTIVE RELIEF. The court in a covered civil action can only grant prospective relief if it is narrowly drawn, minimally intrusive, and necessary to correct a legal violation. Preliminary injunctions for energy projects are limited to 60 days, with possible 30-day extensions requiring court approval. SEC. 407. LIMITATION ON ATTORNEYS' FEES. SEC. 407. LIMITATION ON ATTORNEYS' FEES. The Equal Access to Justice Act does not apply to covered civil actions, and no party in such actions can receive payment from the Federal Government for attorneys' fees, expenses, and court costs. SEC. 408. LEGAL STANDING. Challengers appealing to the Department of the Interior Board of Land Appeals must meet the same standing requirements as challengers in a United States district court.
